results.title: Le Cheval D'orgueil = the Horse of Pride
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Between 1908 and 1918, Pierre-Jakez Helias spent his childhood in Bigouden country (French Brittany). The First World War brings about many changes in the traditional life of a village where pride is more abundant than riches. The central theme of the film is the perpetuation of Brittany’s culture (and language) via oral, rather than written tradition.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writer, Daniel Boulanger ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen ; art direction, Hilton McConnico.
Cast: Jacques Dufilho, Bernadette Le Sache, Francois Cluzet, Dominique Lavanant, Michel Blanc, Paul Le Person, Michel Robin, Georges Wilson [narration only].

results.title: Zazie Dans le Metro = Zazie in the Subway
results.brief_description:
Precocious, foul-mouthed pre-teen Zazie spends three days with her female impersonator uncle Gabriel in Paris with the sole intention of riding the Metro. But everything conspires against her.

Credits: Director, Louis Malle ; writers, Louis Malle, Jean-Paul Rappeneau ; photography, Henri Raichi ; music, Fiorenzo Carpi ; art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Catherine Demongeot, Hubert Deschamps, Jacques Dufilho, Annie Fratellini.

results.title: Les Dernieres Vacances = the Final Holidays
results.brief_description:
In 1933, a couple on the verge of separation decide to sell the family country home. The mansion is a magic house, full of memories for their son Jacques and his cousins, specially Juliette. The teenagers decide to fight against the potential buyer, Gabard. Gabard is a seducer and is immediately smitten by Juliette. Faced with Gabard’s interest, the teenagers realise they are in love with each other.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Gerin ; director, Roger Leenhardt ; writers, Roger Leenhardt, Roger Breuil, Maurice Junod ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Guy Bernard.
Cast: Odile Versois, Michel Francois, Pierre Dux, Renee Devillers, Jean d’ Yd.

results.title: Interdit Aux Moins de 13 Ans = Forbidden to Those Under 13
results.brief_description:
Louis lives a mournful existence in a sad-looking suburb with a wife who refuses to even talk to him. His dream is to drive a truck all the way to Lebanon, but he has no money. One way to finance his dream would be to rob the local supermarket.

Credits: Producers, Klaus Hellwig ; director, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; writers, Jean-Louis Bertucelli, Sandra Majerowicz ; photography, Jean-Francois Robin ; music, Gabriel Yared.
Cast: Patrick Depeyrrat, Sandra Montaigu, Akim Oumaouche, Marilyn Even, Andre Chaumeau.

results.title: L'invitee = the Guest
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Seta and Jean-Roch Rognoni
results.brief_description:
When she discovers her husband has come home with a mistress, Anne leaves her home in Paris and spends the night in her office where she meets Francois, an architect. Without further ado, Francois invites her to a business trip to the South of France.

Credits: Producer, Jean-Roch Rognoni ; director, Vittorio De Seta; writers, Lucile Laks, Tonino Guerra, Frantz Andre Burguet, Vittorio De Seta, Monique Lange ; photography, Luciano Tovoli ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Joanna Shimkus, Jacques Perrin, Lorna Heilbron, Paul Barge, Clotilde Joanno, Jacques Rispal.

results.title: La Cite de L'indicible Peur
results.brief_description:
Mickey, a dangerous mobster, has been arrested ‘by chance’ by Triquet, a rather insignificant police officer. Mickey is condemned to death but manages to escape. Triquet is ordered to trace him all the way to the village of Barges in Auvergne (central France).

Credits: Producer, Paul Laffargue ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Jean-Pierre Mocky, Gerard Klein ; photography, Eugen Schuftan ; music, Gerard Calvi ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Bourvil, Jean-Louis Barrault, Francis Blanche, Veronique Nordey, Jacques Dufilho, Rene-Louis Lafforgue, Jean Poiret, Raymond Rouleau.

results.title: Dites-Lui Que Je L'aime = Tell Her that I'm in Love
results.creator_credit: Claude Miller, Hubert Niogret and Maurice Bernart
results.brief_description:
David is an accountant. He leaves town every Friday, pretending he is going to take care of his parents at their old people’s home. But actually his parents are dead, and he spends the week-ends converting a chalet. He intends to live there with Lise, a woman he knows and loves since childhood. But Lise is married to another and has a baby. David’s mad love does not see those facts as an obstacle…

Credits: Producers, Maurice Bernart, Hubert Niogret ; director, Claude Miller ; writers, Claude Miller, Luc Beraud ; photography, Pierre Lhomme ; music, Alain Jomy ; art director, Hilton McConnico.
Cast: Christian Clavier, Jacques Denis, Gerard Depardieu, Dominique Laffin, Miou-Miou, Claude Pieplu, Josiane Balasko.

results.title: Providence
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Klaus Hellwig, Yves Gasser and Yves Peyrot
results.brief_description:
This is a perversely hilarious comedy about one restless night (among many) in the fading life of ageing, over-sexed novelist, Clive Langham. Clive lives alone in a country mansion and spends his nights cursing his fate as he inserts suppositories, sits on the ‘throne’ and downs bottle after bottle of white wine. In his nightmare, the characters of his novel mix with his real life relatives. As Clive gathers his relatives around him for a final week-end and they attempt to nurse him back to life, he realises that they are not the monsters he perceived them to be.

Credits: Produces, Yves Gasser, Yves Renot, Klaus Hellwig ; director, Alain Resnais ; writers, David Mercer ; photography, Ricardo Aronovitch ; music, Miklos Rozsa ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier.
Cast: Dirk Bogarde, Ellen Burstyn, John Gielgud, David Warner, Elain Stritch, Peter Arne.

results.title: L'annee Derniere a Marienbad = Last Year in Marienbad (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Pierre Courau and Raymond Froment
results.brief_description:
Robbe-Grillet described ‘Marienbad’ as ‘the story of a persuading’ centred on a romantic triangle ending in violence, constructed in the mind of X, one of the three. To Resnais, ‘Marienbad’ looks like a statue and sounds like an opera’. The images of the chateau are those of a labyrinth of fake trails, variants, failures and repetitions, destroying spatial and temporal logic in a film about the processes of memory that locates everything in the present tense. In keeping with Robbe-Grillet’s rejection of conventional interior monologue the emphasis is not on what X is thinking and feeling but on what he ‘sees’. With a hint of playfulness Resnais’ treatment of Robbe-Grillet’s script suggests a meditation on narrative tyranny, a modernist demonstration of narrative cinema as process: instead of the image revealing the world, it reveals itself. Awards: Best Film Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1961 ; Prix Georges Melies 1961 ; Prix Andre Bazin 1961.

Credits: Producers, Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment ; director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Francis Seyrig ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier ; assistant director, Volker Schloendorff.
Cast: Giorgio Albertazzi, Delphine Seyrig, Sacha Pitoeff.

results.title: Clementine Tango
results.brief_description:
Charles, a law student, shares a sumptuous Paris apartment with his sister. One day, he finds a very strange love letter in the pocket of his father’s tuxedo. While trying to understand his father’s love entanglements, he is led to a Pigalle nightclub where act after act is performed with the intent of splintering bourgeois sexual mores into humorous pieces. The ‘cinema du look’ is not quite confined to the films of Beineix, Besson and Carax, the tree neo-baroque ‘wonder boys’. Caroline Roboh’s camp cabaret ‘Clementine Tango’ (1982) belongs to the genre too, as does Virginie Thevenet ‘La nuit porte-jaretelles’ (1985), which led ‘Les Cahiers du Cinema’ to coin the phrase ‘style Forum des Halles’, and prompted an attack from ‘Positif’ on the quality of the narrative, acting, and portrayal of sexuality.” Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Vladimir Forgency ; director, Caroline Roboh ; writer, Caroline Roboh ; photography, Mario Barroso.
Cast: Claire Pascal, Francois Helvey, Caroline Roboh, Arturo Brachetti, Josephine Larsen.
